Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project-Institutional Change through Faculty Advancement in Instruction and Mentoring-ICFAIM

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The implementation project at Jackson State University entitled - Institutional Change through Faculty Advancement in Instruction and Mentoring - builds on two successful previous implementation projects and aims to increase the retention of undergraduate students in the College of Science, Engineering and Technology by helping the faculty and graduate students to improve teaching and mentoring. The project focuses its initial efforts on the Department of Physics, Atmospheric Sciences and Geoscience (PASGS) by piloting faculty development workshops in student-centered pedagogy and delivering professional mentoring. The project also supports the department's efforts to revise the content of entry-level physics courses and their respective labs.

To examine the efficacy of faculty development in mentoring and the development of a research methods course, the project supports students and faculty to increase the number of research opportunities on campus during the academic year and with partner institutions year round. This will increase overall undergraduate research participation. The project will expand from one primarily targeting PASGS to one that is institutionalized within the departments in the college. It offers an opportunity to collect data that will guide the faculty on how to successfully address the particular learning and mentoring needs of African American science,technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate students.

This project has the potential to become a successful model which will be shared with the broader community of colleges and universities that are working to increase the number of minorities entering the scientific and technological workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aggregated Post-Workshop Findings (2014-2019)

ICFAIM's goal was to change faculty perceptions on and to support faculty implementation of novel, evidence-based STEM teaching and mentoring strategies; its cornerstone was providing year-round PD workshops, taught by faculty professors and professionals from nationally recognized academic institutions, to support faculty throughout the school year. Each ICFAIM cycle began with two weeks of summer teaching development, and included such topics as student motivation and engagement, inquiry-based learning, evidence-based approaches for differential learners and underprepared students, and equity and inclusion in STEM. 

All ICFAIM workshops were ranked highly over the course of six years, with participants reporting "A great deal" when asked the extent to which each workshop: (1) provided useful information applicable to their teaching and (2) gave them new ideas and strategies with which to increase student learning (ATTACHED Figure 1). Mean (M) levels increased slightly most years, but remained steady overall. When ICFAIM participants were asked to rate their likelihood of using some strategies learned from each workshop, most reported either "Very likely" (79%) or "Likely" (19%).

 

Improvements in Faculty Knowledge of PD Course Topics

Survey findings showed statistically significant improvement in participants'knowledge from pre to post-session over the first three years of gathering this feedback, with the largest learning curve occurring in 2019 (Pre M = 3.00; Post M = 4.3; ATTACHED Figure 2).

 

Improvements in Faculty Pedagogical Knowledge, Skills & Practice 

Each year, faculty were asked to reflect on the impact of their ICFAIM participation.  The highest reported means (in aggregate) were seen for instructional methods (M = 4.3), closely followed by a deepening knowledge of sciences as a strategy to engage students and retain information (M = 4.1), strategies for teaching underrepresented students in STEM (M = 4.0), and use of technology in creating modules for research (M = 3.9) (ATTACHED Figure 3).

 

Changes in Professional Activities 

Most faculty reported changes in instructional methods (M = 4.3) and approaches for addressing diverse learning styles (M = 4.2). The largest increase or change reported (in aggregate) was seen for engaging in informal self-directed learning, with a total mean change of 3.6 reported (Figure 4). Faculty reported increasing their professional activities from once or twice a semester to once or twice a month.  

 

Participant Post-Assessments of ICFAIM: Benefits of ICFAIM for faculty and students

Participants described the value of ICFAIM resources and tools, and praised the instructors and their ability to teach inquiry-based student learning. The following comment highlights ICFAIM's approach in helping faculty learn the foundations of new teaching strategies and concepts in relation to their students, rather than simply mimicking procedural exercises: 

"Instructors told us, as physics teachers, that we cannot only focus on course content. They pressed us to think about how students may think, based on their own life experience, within the context of these concepts. Such an approach may ensure the greatest success of knowledge transference - from instructors to students."

A multi-year participant reflected on how instructors decide the best approach for integrating new pedagogical practices: "It is up to the faculty to implement the suitable approach provided limitations (time, incentive and other) are minimized." Several faculty members reiterated that many STEM educators were trained as researchers, are considered "experts" in their respective fields, but have not been trained as instructors: 

"Most faculty in STEM disciplines were trained well as researchers but received little to no instruction in teaching strategies and how students learn. The current methods used by most faculty is outdated and don't engage the current students."

Participants agreed that, if instructors participate in this type of PD, their students will exhibit: 1) greater motivation to learn; 2) greater interest in concepts, rendering classes more enjoyable; 3) improved critical thinking skills; and 4) better technology use to support students' studies. 

 

Suggested Improvements to ICFAIM

The majority of participants (78%) wanted more PD sessions and year-round PD support and training. Suggested program improvements included: 1) more self-directed learning, with participants organizing the scope of PD instruction; 2) more strategies for increasing student motivation in STEM; 3) more strategies for increasing retention of science majors; 4) guidance on how to integrate technology in the classroom; and 5) gauging faculty members'commitment to change and integrating what is learned on a regular basis as criterion for program participation.

 

Conclusion

Our findings show that a long-term commitment to faculty PD can change faculty views about STEM teaching, even among those who at first resist altering long-employed approaches to gatekeeper STEM course content material and laboratory experiments. Our findings suggest that, if it is to achieve its goals, STEM faculty PD must be: 1) carefully designed to build on shared standards and knowledge; 2) provided incrementally over time; 3) focused on topics of concern to faculty in addition to presenting new ones; and 4) fairly incentivized.
